item.title: Bitcoin surges as traders bet on Donald Trump election win after shooting - Financial Times
item.description:
1. Bitcoin surges as traders bet on Donald Trump election win after shooting  Financial Times
  2. Morning Bid: Trump hit steepens curve; China's economy judders  Reuters
  3. Bettors See Higher Chance of Trump Election Victory After Assassination Attempt  The Wall Street Journal
  4. Global Markets Ramp Up the ‘Trump Trade’ After Rally Attack  Bloomberg
  5. US markets are steady following assassination attempt on Trump  CNN

item.title: Mystery around Donald Trump shooting: 3 things we don't know
item.description: After FBI identified Donald Trump's shooter as Thomas Matthew Crooks, a lot of information and disinformation have surfaced but there are more questions unanswered even 36 hours after the assassination attempt on Trump. Crooks acted alone and used his father's AR-15-styl rifle to shoot at Trump at the Pennsylvania rally. The bullets grazed Trump's ear while Crooks was shot dead.

item.title: BoE should ‘stop squeezing living standards’ and cut rates, says policymaker
item.description:
Swati Dhingra says Bank of England’s monetary policy committee should lower interest rates in August

  • Business live – latest updates

The Bank of England needs to “stop squeezing living standards” and cut interest rates, a senior policymaker has said.

Swati Dhingra, a member of the central bank’s monetary policy committee (MPC), said official borrowing costs should be cut at its next meeting on 1 August to ease pressure on households and businesses.

Continue reading...

item.title: Wes Streeting defends puberty blocker ban decision after Labour criticism
item.description:
Health secretary said ‘safety of children must come first’ as MPs reacted to move to continue Tory policy

  • UK politics live – latest updates

Wes Streeting, the health secretary, has defended his decision to make permanent a ban on so-called puberty blockers being prescribed to children for gender-based reasons after the move was criticised by a series of Labour MPs.

Streeting cited the Cass review into gender identity services as saying there was currently not enough evidence about the impact on young people of using puberty-suppressing hormones, which are occasionally used for children with gender dysmorphia.

Continue reading...
